A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.

For a monoid $M$ and elements $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n} \in M$, the product is defined as $\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} := a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n}$. A special bracketing on the right-hand side is not necessary due to the associative nature of the law of composition.
Does the concept of a/an Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Product Notation in Monoids to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Ring involves a set with two operations: addition and multiplication, where the set forms a commutative group under addition and a monoid under multiplication. The definition of a Ring also includes the distributive property between these two operations.

On the other hand, the concept of Product Notation in Monoids solely involves the operation of multiplication in a monoid, which is an associative operation with an identity element. This concept does not inherently require the addition operation or the distributive laws that are part of the definition of a Ring.

Therefore, the definition and understanding of Product Notation in Monoids do not depend on the concept of a Ring. The essential properties needed for Product Notation in Monoids are already satisfied by the definition of a monoid itself, which is a simpler structure than a ring and does not include the additional complexities of addition and distributive laws.
